Illusory Retreat (Su) Whenever the saboteur takes the withdraw action, she turns invisible and leaves an illusory duplicate in her place, as the spell mislead. However, the invisibility provided only lasts 1 round, and the major image created cannot be concentrated on. The save DC is equal to her trick DC, as opposed to the normal DC of mislead. The saboteur must be at least 8th level before selecting this trick. Influence (Ex) A saboteur with this trick can easily persuade and deceive her targets. She can roll twice on a Bluff, Diplomacy, Intimidate, Sleight of Hand, or Stealth check she makes against the target of her charlatans mark, or roll twice on a Bluff or Disguise check she made to pass herself as her target, and take the better result. She can only do this once per target she marks with her charlatans mark in a 24 hour period. Intercept (Ex) The saboteur can make an attack of opportunity against the target of her duelists mark when it moves into any square threatened by her, regardless of whether that movement would normally provoke an attack of opportunity. The saboteur must be at least 8th level before selecting this trick. Into Thin Air (Sp) As a move action, the saboteur can vanish from sight, as the spell invisibility. This effect can be used for a number of minutes each day equal to the saboteurs level; this duration does not need to be consecutive, but it must be spent in 1-minute increments. At 12th level, she can instead use this ability to grant herself greater invisibility, but each round spent invisible in such a manner counts as 1 minute of this abilitys duration. The saboteur must be at least 4th level before selecting this trick. Intuitive Mark (Ex) A saboteur with this trick can mark a creature with her marked target class feature, even if she has already done so that day. This doesnt let her maintain more marks than her normal limit. She may do so once per day, plus an additional time each day for every two levels above 10th. The saboteur must be at least 10th level before selecting this trick. Lasting Traps (Ex) The saboteurs traps have a more robust construction. When she places a saboteur trap, she can have it remain set for up to 1 week, instead of only 1 hour per level. A trap set in this manner counts as three traps for the purpose of how many traps the saboteur can have placed at once. The saboteur must be at least 14th level before selecting this trick. Masterful Sabotage (Ex) The saboteur is especially proficient at disabling traps, even among other saboteurs. Whenever she disarms a trap using Disable Device, she can bypass it even if her check did not exceed the DC by 10 or more. If it is a magic trap that allows specific creatures to pass it without danger, she can modify which creatures it allows to pass, adding her allies and restricting enemies if she desires. The saboteur must be at least 6th level before selecting this trick. Mobile Setup (Ex) Whenever the saboteur takes the withdraw action, she can also place a saboteur trap as part of that action at any point during her movement. The saboteur must be at least 12th level before selecting this trick. Nimble (Ex) Once per turn when the saboteur successfully makes a weapon attack against the target of her duelists mark, she may take a 5-foot step. She may do this even if she moved or took a 5-foot step this round, but her total movement in a round cannot exceed her base speed. Opportune Strikes (Ex) Whenever a target of the saboteurs duelists mark misses her with an attack, that target provokes an attack of opportunity from her. A target can only provoke one attack per round from the saboteur in this way. The saboteur must be at least 10th level before selecting this trick. Piercing Strikes (Ex) When attacking the target of her assassins mark, the saboteurs weapons are considered magic, silver, and cold iron for the purpose of bypassing damage reduction. At 12th level, her weapons are considered one alignment type (chaotic, evil, good, or lawful). She can change which alignment type her weapons function as each time she marks a target, but the type chosen must match one axis of the saboteurs alignment. At 16th level, the saboteur ignores the first 5 points of damage reduction possessed by the target of her assassins mark, regardless of type. The saboteur must be at least 8th level before selecting this trick. Poison Brewer (Ex) The saboteur can create poisons cheaply. When she gains this trick, she chooses one ability score except for Constitution. Each day when she prepares her traps, she can use an alchemists lab to brew a number of poisons equal to her Intelligence modifier (minimum 1) at no cost. The poisons effect is based on which ability score she chose (Poisoninjury; save Fort DC equal to the saboteurs trick DC; frequency 1/round for 6 rounds; effect 1d3 damage to the chosen ability score; cure 1 save). These poisons last for only 24 hours before becoming inert. At 12th and 18th levels, she can select another ability score to damage with her poisons, and the damage die increases by one step (to 1d4 at 12th level, and to 1d6 at 18th level). She chooses which ability score from those available to her that a given poison damages when she creates it. The saboteur must be at least 6th level before selecting this trick. Poison Expert (Ex) The saboteur gains a bonus on Craft (alchemy) checks involving poisons equal to half her saboteur level; this does not stack with the bonus from the tinkerer saboteur trick. In addition, she can use Craft (alchemy) to change the type of a poison. This requires 1 hour of work with an alchemists lab and a Craft (alchemy) skill check with a DC equal to the poisons DC. If successful, the poisons type changes to contact, ingested, inhaled, or injury. If the check fails, the poison is ruined. The saboteur must be at least 4th level before selecting this trick. Potent Toxins (Ex) Poisons created by the saboteur are especially lethal against particular foes. When the saboteur takes this trick, she selects a single creature type (and subtype, if she chooses humanoid or outsider) except for construct, similar to a rangers favored enemy. Poisons that the saboteur creates work against those creatures even if they would otherwise be immune to poison, ability damage, or effects that require a Fortitude save. The effects of the poison might still have no effect, depending on what she uses them for (such as trying to inflict Constitution damage to an undead). She selects another creature type (and subtype, where applicable) for every four levels gained past 8th. The saboteur must be at least 8th level before selecting this trick. Quick Hands (Ex) The saboteur gains Quick Draw as a bonus feat. She adds half her saboteur level on Sleight of Hand checks to hide a weapon, and drawing a hidden weapon becomes a swift action for her. This bonus to Sleight of Hand checks does not stack with the bonus on Sleight of Hand checks provided by charlatans mark. Salvage Trap (Ex) The saboteur can salvage traps for use in construction of her own traps. Whenever she successfully disarms a trap, she can spend 10 minutes salvaging materials from it. She gains an amount of raw materials with a gold value equal to 200 gp x the traps CR or 20% of the traps construction cost, whichever is lower. These raw materials can only be used to construct traps, either mundane or magical in nature, but cannot be used as material components for her saboteur trap class feature. A saboteur can only salvage a mechanical trap, not a magic device trap or a spell trap. Secret Passage (Sp) A saboteur with this trick can use magic to enter secure areas. As a full-round action, she can touch a wall to affect it as a passwall spell, using her saboteur level as her caster level. She can use this ability a number of times per day equal to her Intelligence bonus (minimum 1). At 16th level, she can use three of her daily uses of this ability to instead create the effects of a phase door spell. The saboteur must be at least 10th level before selecting this trick. Spell Thief (Sp) A saboteur with this trick can steal magical effects. When she hits an opponent with a weapon attack, as a free action she can siphon some of that targets ongoing spell effects, as an arcana theftUM spell. Alternatively, she can do this when attacking a magic item, transferring the magical effects of the item to her own possessions as a siphon enhancement spell. Both of these effects use her saboteur level as her caster level and her saboteur trick DC in place of the spells normal save DC. She can do this once per day, plus an additional time per day for every two levels beyond 12th. The saboteur must be at least 12th level before selecting this trick. Spot Weakness (Ex) Whenever the saboteur makes only a single weapon attack on her turn against the target of her informants mark (by taking the attack action, using the Spring Attack or Vital Strike feats, etc.), she doubles the critical threat range of that attack. This does not stack with other effects that improve critical threat range, such as Improved Critical. If the target is one she has identified with a Knowledge check, she adds her Intelligence bonus to her damage roll and rolls to confirm critical hits (minimum +0). The saboteur must be at least 8th level before selecting this trick. Tinkerer (Ex) The saboteur gains a bonus on all Craft checks equal to half her saboteur level, and the time it takes for her to create or set mechanical traps is halved. At 8th level, she no longer takes any penalty for using improvised tools for Disable Device or Craft checks. Trackless (Ex) The saboteur leaves no footprints or scent, as if under the constant effect of a pass without trace spell. In addition, the saboteur can move at full speed while using the Stealth skill without penalty. Underhanded Tactics (Ex) Whenever the saboteur hits the target of her charlatans mark with a weapon attack, she can strike it a vulnerable spot, sickening for 1 round. If the target was denied their Dexterity bonus to AC when struck, it is sickened for 1d3+1 rounds, instead. This duration does not stack. The saboteur must be at least 10th level before selecting this trick. Unreadable (Sp) The saboteur is an enigma to outside divinations. She is treated as though under the effect of a mind blank spell, using her saboteur level as her caster level. She can suspend or resume this ability as a standard action; if its dispelled she cannot resume it for 1 minute. The saboteur must be at least 16th level before selecting this trick. Versatile Assembly (Ex) The saboteur gains a bonus metaconstruction feat of her choice. At 10th level, she can spontaneously apply the effects of her chosen metaconstruction feat to saboteur traps she places. How many times per day she can do this is based on the level adjustment the metaconstruction feat has on her saboteur traps a feat with a +1 level adjustment can be used three times per day, a feat with a +2 level adjustment can be used twice a day, and a feat with a +3 level adjustment can be used once per day. She cannot use this effect with the Heighten Trap metaconstruction feat. The saboteur must be at least 4th level before selecting this trick.
prerequisites: sniper (ex) the saboteur gains precise shot as a bonus feat, even if she doesnt meet the . when she uses the stealth skill to snipe, she only suffers a -10 penalty to stealth, instead of -20.
benefits: shifting aura (su) the saboteur can mask her true alignment, even fooling magical senses. as a standard action, she can choose to detect as a specific alignment. spells and effects that rely on her alignment (such as detect good or a paladins smite evil) treat her as if she were the chosen alignment. this applies to both helpful and harmful. the effect lasts until the saboteur dismisses it (a standard action). the saboteur must be at least 14th level before selecting this trick.

name: Extra Secret
description: Nature has taught you another hidden power. Special You can gain this feat multiple times.
prerequisites: benefit you gain an additional secret. you must meet all of the for this secret.

name: Warden - Secrets
description: A wardens devotion to nature is rewarded with knowledge of its hidden mysteries. When he reaches 2nd level and every three warden levels thereafter, he gains a single secret from the list below. A secret cannot be selected more than once. If a secret calls for a saving throw, the DC is equal to 10 + 1/2 the wardens level + his Wisdom modifier unless otherwise noted. Alleviate (Su) When the warden uses remedy on a creature, it is no longer sickened. At 8th level, it is no longer nauseated, as well. Bond of Vitality (Su) An invisible thread of protection allows a warden to intercept harm from his allies. As a standard action, the warden can form a bond of vitality with a willing creature within 30 feet of himself. Whenever that creature takes damage, the amount it takes is reduced by 1/4 the wardens level. If the creature is inside one of the wardens wards, it is reduced by 1/2 the wardens level, instead. The warden takes all damage prevented this way, and cannot reduce this redirected damage by any means. He can maintain a number of bonds equal to his Wisdom modifier (minimum 1). Bonds last until the warden is reduced to 0 hit points, the bonded creature dies, the distance between them exceeds medium range (100 ft. + 10 ft./level), or the warden ends it as an immediate action (the warden can end one or several bonds at once with the same action). The warden must be at least 5th level before learning this secret. Cleansing (Sp) The warden can spend a use of remedy to cast remove curse as a spell-like ability. This has the same range of his remedy class feature. The warden must be at least 8th level before learning this secret. Convalescence (Sp) The warden can spend 2 uses of remedy to cast restoration as a standard action and without material components, using the same range as his remedy class feature. He cannot use this to dispel a permanent negative level. The warden must be at least 11th level before learning this secret. Cycle of Growth (Sp) The warden can bless plant life to spread wildly or prune it for their long-term health. He can use both diminish plants and plant growth at-will as spell-like abilities using his warden level as his caster level. The warden must be at least 11th level before learning this secret. Eyes of the Wild (Sp) The warden can cast both commune with nature and find the path (targeting himself only) at will as spell-like abilities, but must use their normal casting time. The warden must be at least 14th level before learning this secret. Forest Traveler (Sp) The warden can use tree stride as a spell-like ability number of times per day equal to his Wisdom modifier (minimum 1), plus an additional use per day when he reaches 14th and 20th levels. At 14th level, he can use two uses of this ability to instead cast transport via plants. The warden must be at least 8th level before learning this secret. Green Thumb (Ex) The warden gains Cultivate Magic PlantsUW as a bonus feat without meeting its requirements and can ignore the spell requirements in the creation of magical plants. The warden must be at least 5th level before learning this secret. Grow Anew (Sp) The warden can spend 6 uses of remedy to cast resurrection without material components, using his warden level as his caster level. He must use its normal casting time and range. The warden must be at least 17th level before learning this secret. Guardians Reflex (Ex) A warden with this secret can more ably react to his opponents. He gains a +1 insight bonus on attack and damage rolls made as part of an attack of opportunity and can make an additional attack of opportunity each round. These additional attacks stack with those gained from the Combat Reflexes feat (if he has it). At 8th, 14th, and 20th levels, the bonus to attack and damage rolls and the number of attacks of opportunity he can make increase by 1, to a total of a +4 bonus and four additional attacks of opportunity per round. Guided Hand (Ex) A consistent assault can fell even the toughest foes. Whenever the warden takes the attack action to make a single attack, he adds half his warden level to the damage dealt. This damage is the same type as the weapon used and is multiplied on a critical hit. In addition, if the warden uses the Vital Strike feat (or its variants), he multiplies the additional damage by the number of dice rolled by those feats twice for Vital Strike, three times for Improved Vital Strike, or four times for Greater Vital Strike. The damage increase for Vital Strike (and its variants) is applied before factoring in critical hits. The warden must be at least 5th level before learning this secret. Hidden Trails (Ex) The warden gains woodland stride, as the druid class feature of the same name, and does not leave a trail while traveling through natural terrains (as pass without trace) unless he so desires. At 8th level, he may move at full speed through thorns, briars, and overgrown areas that are enchanted or magically manipulated, including areas that would impart the entangled condition, and his ability to leave no trail while traveling may be extended to all of his allies, so long as they remain within 30 feet of him while traveling. Leyline Walker (Su) The wardens wild step improves. If he uses his wild step to teleport into one of his own wards (but not a ward from another warden), he can do so from any distance. Additionally, the warden can use his wild step as a standard action to bring a single willing, adjacent creature along with him when he teleports. The brought creature must end its teleportation adjacent to the warden and inside the destination ward. The warden must be at least 14th level before learning this secret. Like the Reed (Sp) The warden can bend and twist wood. He can cast warp wood and wood shape as spell-like abilities at-will using his warden level as his caster level and secret DC for the spell DC. The warden must be at least 5th level before learning this secret. Monster Hunter (Ex) New threats must be known before they can be properly dealt with. The warden adds half his level as a bonus to Knowledge checks made to identify creatures and can make such checks untrained. This does not stack with the bonus from nature lore. Mountains Gift (Ex) The steadfast spirits of the mountain bless the warden with a climb speed equal to his base speed (including a +8 racial bonus to Climb checks). The warden must be at least 5th level before learning this secret. Mystic Blade (Su) The warden can call upon the myriad spirits of the wild to inhabit his weapon and give him strength. As a swift action, the warden can grant a weapon he is holding a +1 enhancement bonus for 1 minute. For every three levels beyond 8th, the weapon gains another +1 enhancement bonus, to a maximum of +5 at 20th level. These bonuses stack with existing weapon enhancements to a maximum of +5. Alternatively, the enhancement bonus can be used to add any of the following weapon properties brutal, defending, flaming, flaming burst, frost, glacial, guardian, icy burst, impact, lifesurge, limning, merciful, shock, and shocking burst. Adding these properties consumes an amount of bonus equal to the propertys base price modifier. Duplicate abilities do not stack. If the weapon is not magical, at least a +1 enhancement bonus must be added before any other properties can be added. Bonuses granted by mystic blade do not function if the weapon is wielded by anyone other than the warden. He may use this ability a number of times per day equal to his Wisdom modifier (minimum 1). The warden must be at least 8th level before learning this secret. Natural Order (Sp) The warden can spend 2 uses of remedy to cast break enchantment as a standard action, using his warden level as his caster level for the effect. This has the same range as his remedy class feature but only targets a single creature. The warden must be at least 14th level before learning this secret. Naturalize (Sp) The warden can spend 1 use of remedy to cast dispel magic as a standard action, using his warden level as his caster level for the effect. The warden must be at least 5th level before learning this secret. Oceans Gift (Ex) The mysterious spirits of the ocean bless the warden with a swim speed equal to his base speed (including a +8 racial bonus to Swim checks). This also grants the warden the ability to breathe underwater. The warden must be at least 5th level before learning this secret. Prevention (Su) An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure. The warden can spend 1 use of remedy as a standard action to grant a creature 1d6 temporary hit points per two warden levels; this has the same range as remedy. These temporary hit points last for 1 hour and do not stack. Once a creature has received this effect, they cannot receive it again for 1 hour from the same warden. Renewal (Sp) The warden can spend a use of remedy to cast remove blindness/deafness as a spell-like ability. This has the same range of his remedy class feature. The warden must be at least 8th level before learning this secret. Return to Nature (Su) The wardens touch can undo artifice, making way for nature to reclaim it. The warden can touch an object or construct as a standard action to inflict 1d6 damage per two warden levels (max 10d6) to the target. A Fortitude save by the touched object or creature halves the damage dealt. Once an object or a construct is affected by this ability (whether it saves or not) it cannot be targeted again for 24 hours. Sacred Grove (Sp) A warden with this secret can conjure an aspect of the hidden wellsprings where spirits rest. The warden can cast grove of respiteAPG as a spell-like ability at-will. When he does, he can optionally create a lodge for his allies, as a secure shelter spell, inside the groves area. Creating a sacred grove takes 10 minutes and uses the wardens level as his caster level for all effects. This can only be used outdoors, and he may only have one sacred grove conjured at a time; using it again causes any existing grove to vanish. The warden must be at least 8th level before learning this secret. Shamans Cure (Sp) The warden may spend one use of his remedy ability to cast his choice of either remove disease or neutralize poison; both effects have the same range as his remedy class feature. Both use the wardens level as his caster level for their effects. The warden must be at least 5th level before learning this secret. Sharpened Senses (Ex) The wardens senses hone like that of a wild animal. He gains both low-light vision and the scent ability. Thread of Life (Su) The glow of life becomes visible to the warden. He gains lifesense, as the universal monster rule, allowing him to notice and locate living creatures within 30 feet as if he had blindsight. The warden must be at least 11th level before learning this secret. Thrive in Nature (Ex and Sp) Wardens are well known for their ability to survive in any climate. A warden with this secret gains Endurance as a bonus feat and can cast detect snares and pits at-will as a spell-like ability. He also gains a +4 bonus to saving throws against natural hazards and weather, including extreme temperatures. At 8th level, the warden takes half the damage from any natural hazard or weather that could deal damage to him (such as nonlethal damage from severe cold, exposure to lava, or being struck by lightning during a storm). Veneration (Su) An air of mystical authority surrounds the warden, deterring even supernatural beings. The wardens reverence ability now also functions against fey and magical beasts. The warden must be at least 17th level before learning this secret. Verdant Sight (Su) The warden can see through undergrowth, gaining the greensight universal monster ability to a range of 60 feet. At 14th level, the warden can even see through wood and other solid plant matter up to a number of feet equal to his warden level. The warden must be at least 8th level to learn this secret. Wilderness Scholar (Ex) When rolling a skill that has a bonus from his nature lore ability, the warden can take 10 on the check, even if distractions would otherwise prevent him from taking 10. The warden must be at least 5th level before learning this secret. Words of Wisdom (Ex) Whenever the warden uses the aid another action to assist one of his allies, the bonus he grants is increased by 1. The bonus increases by an additional 1 at 8th, 14th, and 20th levels.
prerequisites: nature arcana (sp) the warden learns a small selection of natural magics. choose any four from the following list create water, cultivate, detect magic, detect poison, diagnose diseaseum, guidance, know direction, light, purify food and drink, read magic, spark, and stabilize. the warden can cast these spells at-will using his warden level as his caster level. the dc of these spells is equal to 10 + his wisdom modifier. additionally, a warden with this secret is treated as if he were a spellcaster with the druid spell list (and with a caster level equal to his warden level) for the purpose of activating spell trigger and spell completion items or for meeting feat that require the ability to cast druid spells, such as grasping strikeacg.
benefits: whispers among the trees (su) the warden can communicate with natural life. he is constantly under the effect of a speak with animals spell. at 8th level, he also from the constant effect of a speak with plants spell. both effects can be suppressed and reactivated as free actions.

name: Extra Secret of the Pale
description: Your delve into the secrets of life and death are unceasing, constantly expanding your abilities. Special This feat can be selected multiple times, allowing you to select a different secret of the pale each time it is selected.
prerequisites: pale theologian, secrets of the pale class feature
benefits: you gain an additional secret of the pale.

name: Pale Theologian
description: Long ago there existed a group known as the Cult of Fathoms; this group of mages, clerics, and scholars sought to uncover the secrets of reality itself, the fundamental nature of divinity, and the building blocks that formed the universe. The Cult of Fathoms was divided into multiple sects, each focusing on a small aspect of reality that most interested them. One of these sects, known as the Deathkeepers, sought to unveil the secrets of death itself. These master necromancers uncovered ancient rituals that granted them lichdom, but even immortality did not satisfy them. They always felt there was more to uncover. Secrets left untapped. A small few of this sect eventually turned towards life magic; for what was death without life? Viewed as heretical or foolish by their fellow scholars, they carried on. Progress was slow and difficult, but they studies provided enough minor successes that the rest of their sect quickly joined their minds to the task. Their studies finally revealed to them the truth they sought, one they viewed as obvious and hindsight. Death and Life were not separate, but two sides of the same coin. Positive and negative energies were not opposites, but simply variations of the same base energy which they called the Pale. Using this newfound knowledge expanded their powers significantly. It revealed to them methods of necromantic healing lost the the ages, the ability to create undead who responded positively to positive energy, and the ability to infuse living flesh with negative energy without its usual deadly effects. The Deathkeepers expanded their organization in an attempt to publicize their findings and to bring the art of pale necromancy to the forefront. They argued that their art could revolutionize the world; healing made simpler and easier to perform without the reliance on the gods, undead infused with positive energy that did not mean the living harm, and other miracles their studies provided them. The gods of Death and Life did not view such blasphemies favorably, raising up legions of their follows to strike down the Deathkeepers, and eventually the Cult of Fathoms itself. After being thoroughly routed the surviving members Cult of Fathoms scattered to the winds, the knowledge of their organization and the secrets their discovered faded into antiquity. The knowledge of the Pale, however, was passed down by the few remaining ancestors of the Deathkeepers, eventually renaming themselves to the Palekeepers. This secretive sect of pale necromancers has persisted into modern times, seeking out others who they deem worthy of their knowledge or who seem naturally inclined to the mastery of both life and death magic. Most notable of this group are the pale theologians; users of both arcane and divine magics who have dedicated their lives to the study and utilization of the Pale, infusing and corrupting their minds and bodies with its power. These talented spellcasting roam the world in search of ancient secrets to bring back to their order, potential students, and to bring the energies and Death and Life to a balance. Pale theoligians often begin their journey as either necromancers of arcane or divine magic who seek greater understanding of their arts and are sought out by members of the order, but a rare few natural pale theologians discover the secrets of the pale on their own. Eventually learning to combine both arcane and divine magics, these skills mages are true masters of necromancy. Utilizing their magics they can support their allies, ward themselves from the negative effects of death, prolong their lives, animate the dead, heal the sick and dying, or bring death and plague to their foes. Alignment Any. Pale theologians are found from all walks of life, and the art of pale necromancy can be as easily used for good as it can be for ill. Hit Die d6 Starting Wealth 3d6 x 10 gp (average 105 gp). In addition, each character begins play with an outfit worth 10 gp or less. Class Skills The pale theologians class skills are Appraise (Int), Craft (Int), Diplomacy (Cha), Heal (Wis), Knowledge (arcana) (Int), Knowledge (history) (Int), Knowledge (local) (Int), Knowledge (nobility) (Int), Knowledge (religion) (Int), Linguistics (Int), Perception (Wis), Profession (Wis), Sense Motive (Wis), Spellcraft (Int), Stealth (Dex), and Use Magic Device (Cha). Skill Ranks Per Level 2 + Int modifier. Class Features Weapon and Armor Proficiency A pale theologian is proficient with all simple weapons and light armor. At 1st level, the pale theologian decides whether their magic is derived from an arcane source or a divine source. Once chosen, the pale theologians source of magic cannot be changed. Pale theologians who choose arcane as their source of magic suffer from arcane spell failure, and use Intelligence to determine their spellcasting abilities. To learn, prepare, or cast a spell, an arcane pale theologian must have an Intelligence score equal to at least 10 + the spells level. The saving throw DC against a pale theologians spell is 10 + the spells level + the pale theologians Intelligence modifier. An arcane pale theologian can cast pale theologian spells while wearing light armor without incurring the normal arcane spell failure chance. Pale theologians who choose the divine as their source of magic use Wisdom to determine their spellcasting abilities. To learn, prepare, or cast a spell, a divine pale theologian must have a Wisdom score equal to at least 10 + the spells level. The saving throw DC against a pale theologians spell is 10 + the spells level + the pale theologians Wisdom modifier. Pale theologians combine the teachings of both arcane and divine magic to gain mastery over death, blending the two schools into a single form of magic. Pale theologians cast spells drawn from both the cleric and wizard spell lists, with a number of restrictions based on the source of their magic. They treat all of these spells as arcane or divine, based on their choice of magic (no matter whether the spell was originally a cleric or wizard spell). Arcane pale theologians treat all non-necromancy school wizard spells of 1st level or higher as 1 spell level higher. They treat all non-necromancy school cleric spells of 1st level or higher as 2 spell levels higher. For example; an arcane pale theologian would treat a 1st level evocation spell as 2nd level if it is a wizard spell, or 3rd level if it is a cleric spell. Divine pale theologians treat all non-necromancy school cleric spells of 1st level or higher as 1 spell level higher. They treat all non-necromancy school wizard spells of 1st level or higher as 2 spell levels higher. For example; a divine pale theologian would treat a 1st level evocation spell as 2nd level if itis a cleric spell, or 3rd level if it is a wizard spell. If a spell appears on both the cleric and wizard lists of differing spell levels, the pale theologian uses the lower of the two spell levels after adjusting their level above. A pale theologian can only cast a certain number of spells of each spell level per day. Their base daily spell allotment is given on Table Pale Theologian under Spells per Day. In addition, they receive bonus spells per day if they have a high spellcasting ability score; Intelligence for arcane, Wisdom for divine. A pale theologian may know any number of spells, but the number they can prepare each day is limited. At 1st level, they can prepare four 0-level spells and two 1st-level spells each day. At each new pale theologian level, the number of spells they can prepare each day increases, adding new spell levels as indicated on Table Pale Theologian Spells Prepared. Unlike the number of spells they can cast per day, the number of spells a pale theologian can prepare each day is not affected by their spellcasting ability score. Feats and other effects that modify the number of spells known by a spellcaster instead affect the number of spells a pale theologian can prepare. A pale theologian must choose and prepare their spells ahead of time by getting 8 hours of sleep and spending 1 hour studying their spellbook. While studying, the pale theologian decides what spells to prepare and refreshes their available spell slots for the day. Like a sorcerer, the pale theologian can choose to apply any metamagic feats they know to a prepared spell as they cast it, with the same increase in casting time. However,they may also prepare a spell with any metamagic feats they know and cast it without increasing casting time like a wizard. They cannot combine these optionsa spell prepared with metamagic feats cannot be further modified with another metamagic feat at the time of casting. Pale theologians combine the study of divine and arcane magics to fuel their powers, containing their findings and unique methods of casting spells in a specially prepared tome called a spellbook. A pale theologian must study their spellbook each day to prepare their spells. They cant prepare any spell not recorded in their spellbook, except for read magic (which all pale theologians can prepare from memory). A pale theologian begins play with a spellbook containing all 0-level wizard and cleric spells plus three 1st-level spells of their choice. The pale theological also selects a number of additional 1st-level spells equal to their spellcasting ability modifier (Intelligence for arcane, Wisdom for divine) to add to the spellbook. At each new pale theologian level, they gain two new spells of any spell level or levels that they can cast (based on their new pale theologian level) for their spellbook. A pale theologian can also add additional spells to their spellbook.They can add cleric and wizard spells found as scrolls to their spellbook, and add spells found in another pale theologians or wizards spell book to their own. This follows the same rules as a wizard copying spells to their spellbook. A pale theologian can also add cleric spells to their spellbook through the aid of another cleric. A divine caster can preach the working of a cleric spell to the pale theologian while they copy the teaching in to their spellbook. This process is similar to them copying a spell from another casters spellbook to their own, but it requires a divine spellcaster with the desired spell prepared to be present for the entire duration, and then for them to expend the spell at the end of the required time. This process requires the same expense in gold pieces as copying a spell from a wizard spellbook. Hiring a divine spellcaster to teach you a spell usually costs the amount to purchase the spell to be cast for you, often with an additional cost based on the time required. Pale theologians can also research their spells independently, as a wizard. When they do so, the spell counts as an arcane spell on the wizard spell list. Pale theologians can prepare a number of cantrips, or 0-level spells, each day as noted on Table Pale Theologian Spells Prepared. These spells are cast like any other spell, but they do not consume spell slots. As with their other spells, these spells are not expended when cast. Pale theologians treat the following spells as necromancy spells of the listed level, rather than their normal school and level, when determining their spell list stabilize (0 level), cure light wounds (1st level), remove sickness (1st level), cure moderate wounds (2nd level), lesser restoration (2nd level), remove paralysis (2nd level), cure serious wounds (3rd level), remove blindness/deafness (3rd level), remove curse (3rd level), remove disease (3rd level), symbol of healing (3rd level), cure critical wounds (4th level), restoration (4th level), mass cure light wounds (5th level), pillar of life (5th level), raise dead (5th level), mass cure light wounds (6th level), heal (6th level), greater restoration (7th level), mass cure serious wounds (7th level), resurrection (7th level), mass cure critical wounds (8th level), mass heal (9th level), true resurrection (9th level). Spells affected by this ability retain any descriptors they possess, and their effects do not change. For example, a cure light wounds cast by a pale theologian would be treated as a 1st level necromancy spell with the healing descriptor, and it would still heal living creatures and harm undead creatures. Pale theologians can convert their magical power directly into necromantic power, allowing them to cast a number of spells spontaneously using their spell slots. Whenever the pale theologian rests and regains their spell slots, they can choose to either harness the power of healing magics, or harming magics. Until the next time they regain their spell slots, they can spontaneously cast a number of spells based on their choice. If these spells require an expensive material component, the pale theologian is required to provide it as normal for casting the spell. If they chose healing magics, they can spend any of their spell slots to cast one of the following spells of equal to or lower level than the spent spell slot all cure spells (a cure spell is any spell with cure in its name), lesser restoration, restoration, remove disease, neutralize poison, remove curse, greater restoration, heal, mass heal. If they chose harming magics, they can spend any of their spell slots to cast a one of the following spells of equal to or lower level than the spent spell slot all inflict spells (an inflict spell is any spell with inflict in its name), contagion, greater contagion, poison, bestow curse, enervation, major curse, harm, mass harm. The pale theologian can cast the spells they selected from memory and can prepare them using their normal allotment of spells prepared without the need of their spellbook. A pale theologian has learned to tap into a reservoir of power which they can pull from to fuel the powers of the pale. This pool contains a number of points per day equal to their Charisma modifier (minimum 1). At 2nd level, and every 2 levels thereafter, the pale theologian gains an additional 1 theology point. Theology points can be spent to fuel any of the pale theologians class features that require their expenditure. At 1st level, the pale theologian learns to imbue their pale magics within a corpse to raise it as an undead creature, or within a living or undead creature to bolster their attunement to the pale and to restore their wounds. They choose one of the following abilities at 1st level. Once this ability has been chosen, it cannot be changed The effects of this ability persist for 1 minute per class level, though the pale theologian can end the effect early by touching the target again as a swift action. Creatures who are neither living nor undead (such as constructs) cannot be affected by this ability. At 3rd level, the effects of this ability persist for 10 minutes per class level. At 5th level, this ability may be used on (and removed from) creatures within Close range (25 feet + 5 feet per 2 class levels), rather than only touch range, and the pale theologian may apply this ability as a move action. At 7th level, the effects of this ability persist for 1 hour per class level. At 9th level, the range of this ability increases to Medium range (100 feet + 10 feet per class level). At 11th level, the effects of this ability persist for 1 day per 5 class levels, and they may apply this ability as a swift action. Additionally, the pale theologian can rapidly imbue a creature with pale energies to restore their wounded form. The pale theologian can touch a living or undead creature as a standard action and spend 1 theology point to immediately restore 1d6+ their Charisma modifier points of damage to the touched creature. This healing increases by an additional 1d6 at 3rd level, and every 2 levels thereafter. At 1st level, the pale theologian can touch a single corpse as a standard action and spend 1 theology point to animate it as lesser animate dead, using their class level as their caster level. When using this ability, the pale theologian can choose to cast it without the need of expensive material components, but when they do so the created undead has a number of restrictions the undeads duration is reduced to 1 minute per class level and the pale theologian can only have a single undead creature created using this ability active at a time. When the duration of this ability expires, or the pale theologian created a second undead using this ability, the magic leaves the corpse, halting its animation. This does not destroy the corpse, allowing it to be animated again. When doing so, it has the same amount of hit points as when the effects of this ability ended. This created undead still counts against the pool of undead the pale theologian can control using animate dead. At 3rd level, undead created without material components now have a duration of 10 minutes per class level. At 5th level, this ability functions as animate dead. At 7th level, undead created without material components now have a duration of 1 hour per class level. At 9th level, the pale theologian can now control two undead created without material components at a time. At 11th level, undead created without material components now have a duration of 2 hours per class level. At 1st level, the pale theologian can touch a corpse as a standard action and spend 1 theology point to preserve it for 24 hours, extending the time limit on raising it from the dead. During these 24 hours the corpse does not rot, and does not smell. At 2nd level, and every two levels thereafter, a secret of the pale reveals itself to the pale theologian, allowing them to obtain powers and abilities unheard of to those who only dabble in the powers of life or death. See Secrets of the Pale Constant exposure to the pale arts of life and death permanently mars the body of the pale theologian, corrupting it into a state of not quite life and not quite undeath. At 3rd level, the pale theologian gains their first corruption from the list below. They gain additional pale corruptions at their stated level. If a corruption requires a saving throw, it has a DC equal to 10 + 1/2 their pale theologian level + their Charisma modifier. See Pale Corruption Replacements As a swift action, the pale theologian can spend 1 theology point to suppress the energy of life or death within them for 1 hour, allowing them to only be treated as a living creature(healed fully by positive energy, damaged by negative) or only treated as an undead creature (healed fully by negative energy, damaged by positive) for effects that affect living or undead creatures. They can choose to suppress or activate this effect as a free action, but the duration continues to expire while it is suppressed. Once per turn as a free action while this ability is active they can choose to change whether they are suppressing life energy or death energy. At 7th level, the pale theologians connection to the pale further corrupts their body, causing their eyes to glow with a baleful radiance, alerting others to their nature and granting them sight much like an undead creature. The pale theologian gains Darkvision 60 feet, or 120 feet if they already possessed natural Darkvision. This Darkvision is an extraordinary effect. As a standard action they can focus their vision, allowing them to see pale energies. Until the end of their next turn, the pale theologian can determine whether creatures and corpses they can see within Close range (25 feet + 5 feet per 2 pale theologian levels) of them are alive, undead, or neither alive nor undead within Close range of them. They can also detect the general health of living and undead creatures while using this ability, determining whether they are wounded (see below) and if they are affected by a disease or poison. When the pale theologian activates this ability, they may spend 1 theology point to extend its duration to 1 minute. At the end of this duration, they can spend another theology point to extend its duration another minute. If a creatures true nature is being obscured by an illusion or transmutation effect, the pale theologian gains a free Will save or Perception check against the illusion or disguise the first time they perceive it with this ability. This ability is a supernatural effect. When detecting the health of living or undead creatures the pale theologian determines the creatures general condition as determined below. At 11th level, the energy that corrupts the pale theologian causes them to project an unnatural presence that unnerves most natural creatures. Animals, Magical Beasts, and Plant creatures have their starting attitude towards the pale theologian reduced by 1 step. As a standard action, the pale theologian can empower their unnerving presence, causing the above creatures to not approach within Close range of them until the end of the pale theologians next turn. Affected creatures within Close range of them when they activate this ability, or if they begin the turn in its area, must make a Will saving throw or attempt to flee the area on their next turn. On a success, they are immune to this ability until the beginning of their next turn. Above creatures with an Intelligence score of 3 or higher can attempt to enter the area by making a Will saving throw when they attempt to enter it. On a success, they become immune to the effects of this ability until the beginning of their next turn. On a failure, they cannot enter the area and cannot try to do so again until the beginning of their next turn, but can otherwise continue movement. This ability is a mind-affecting fear effect. Additionally, mindless undead always have a starting attitude of Indifferent to the pale theologian, and will only attack if provoked or ordered to by a spellcaster that controls them. Intelligent undead have their starting attitude increased to indifferent if their attitude would normally start at hostile or unfriendly. Intelligent undead are usually curious of the pale theologian, rather than outright hostile, but some intelligent undead may still attack the pale theologian without cause. The pale theologian also becomes immune to disease, poison, and to effects that require a Fortitude save unless the effect also works on objects or are harmless. At 19th level, the pale theologians study of the forces of life and death combined with the pale energies infusing their body has fundamentally altered their mind, their thoughts realigning to perfectly understand the hidden obscurities of death and life. They become immune to all mind-affecting effects (charms, compulsions, morale effects, patterns, and phantasms), fear effects, sleep effects, and stunning. At 20th level, the pale theologian advances their body beyond death itself. Their Constitution score becomes , and they gain a +4 bonus to their Charisma score. The pale theologian uses their Charisma to determine their hit points, Fortitude saving throws, and abilities that would normally be based off of their Constitution. The pale theologian ceases to age. If they are slain and their body is not destroyed, they are immediately reanimated as a zombie lord at full hit points. After 1 week passes they automatically return to life at full hit points. If they are slain before this week passes, this ability cannot save them again. At 5th level, the pale theologian has learned rites that grant them unique methods of defending themselves against undead creatures and the effects of life and death magic. The pale theologian gains a +1 competence bonus on AC and CMD against undead, on saving throws against the extraordinary, supernatural, and spell-like abilities of undead creatures, and on saving throws against death effects, and effects that deal with positive or negative energy. These bonuses increase by an additional +1 at 10th, 15th, and 20th level. At 9th level, the pale theologian can bestow special funerary rites to a slain creature that prevents them from being raised from the dead or reanimated as an undead creature. Performing these rites requires the slain creatures corpse to be within their reach for 1 minute, and an expenditure of 1 point from their theology pool. When performed, anyone who attempts to raise the creature from the dead, or attempts to make an undead from the creatures corpse, must make a caster level check with a DC of 11 + the pale theologians class level. If they fail this check their attempt fails, and they cannot attempt to raise or reanimate the corpse again for 24 hours. If this ability is used against the corpse of an undead creature who cannot be destroyed by conventional means (such as a bloody skeleton) with a number of hit dice equal to or lower than the pale theologians class level, that undead is destroyed permanently. This ability can only be used in this way against undead whose physical bodies restore themselves, and cannot be used against creatures like a ghost or a lich. Particularly powerful creatures may be immune or resistant to this function of the ability, at the GMs discretion. At 15th level, the pale theologian can bestow special restorative rites to a corpse to imbue it with life and unlife in equal measure, temporarily reanimating it. Performing these rites requires the slain creatures corpse to be within their reach for 1 minute, and an expenditure of at least 3 points from their theology pool. When performed, the creature returns to life for 24 hours at 1 hit point. For every 3 additional theology points they spend as part of this rite, the duration is extended by an additional 24 hours. At any time during this time, the pale theologian may perform these rites on that creature again to extend the duration further. At 19th level, the pale theologians studies have revealed to them methods of breaking or subverting the command a spellcaster holds over an undead creature. Whenever the pale theologian successfully identifies an undead creature using Knowledge (religion), they immediately learn whether the undead is being controlled by magic or not. As a standard action they can spend one point from their theology pool to attempt to subvert or break the control over an undead within Medium range (100 feet + 10 feet per pale theologian level), rolling 1d20 and adding their class level + 5 against a DC equal to 11 + the controllers caster level. If they succeeds and the target is a mindless undead, they can either choose to break the spellcasters control (causing the undead to become free-willed) or take control of the undead (adding it to the pool of undead they control using animate dead or Command Undead if they possess the feat). If they succeed and the target is an intelligent undead, they can only choose to break the magic controlling it unless they possess the Command Undead feat, in which case they can gain command using that feat as part of this ability. The path of pale theology is sometimes guided by intense loss and a desire to regain, rather than control over natural forces. A pale theologian must select the imbue with unlife ability with their pale imbuement to select this alternate class feature. Alternatively, if they later gain the imbue with unlife ability using the Expanded Imbuement secret, they can choose to gain this alternate class feature and apply it to that ability. Once they make this choice, it cannot be changed. The bonded in death may only have a single undead created using their imbue with unlife ability at a time. This undead creature is inhabited by the soul of a loved one lost to the bonded in death, known as their dearly departed. If they create a second undead using imbue with unlife while they already have an undead created, they must choose which of the two to destroy. The dearly departed is fiercely loyal to the bonded in death and possesses intelligence which they use to act with the reanimated corpses body. At 1st level, assign one of each of the following scores to the dearly departeds Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma 16, 14, 12. Each score can only be assigned to one ability. Rather than using the mental ability scores of the mindless undead, the undead created by your imbue with unlife uses the dearly departeds mental ability scores. The dearly departed grants the undead creature it possesses skill ranks and feats based on the bonded in deaths level, granting one feat at 1st level and every 2 class levels thereafter, and grants 2 + the dearly departeds Intelligence modifier skill ranks for each level of the bonded in death, with a maximum number of ranks in any one skill equal to the bonded in deaths level. The dearly departed treats every skill as a class skill. The dearly departed also gains an increase to their channel resistance equal to their Charisma modifier. At 4th level, and every 4 levels thereafter, one of the dearly departeds mental ability scores is increased by 1 point. The dearly departed shares the languages of the bonded in death and can speak even if it would have been unable to in life. These feats and skill ranks are chosen each time the bonded in death gains a class level. This modifies the pale theologians pale imbuement class feature. Special This alternate class feature can be combined with the spectral reanimator alternate class feature, despite them both modifying the same class feature. When doing so, the bonded in deaths dearly departed is animated as a specter without the need of a corpse, has a number of hit dice equal to the dearly departeds class level, and at 1st level the following ability scores are assigned to the dearly departeds Dexterity, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma 16, 16, 14, 12. Each score can only be assigned to one ability. The dearly departeds Dexterity gains a +2 bonus, as normal for a specter, but their other mental ability scores are not modified or replaced. At 4th level, and every 4 levels thereafter, the bonded in death increases one of these ability scores by 1. If the bonded in deaths spectral dearly departed is destroyed, the next time they attempt to create them using their imbue with death ability it costs an additional 2 theology points, which returns the dearly departed to full hit points. This otherwise follows all other rules and restrictions of both alternate class features. The bonded in death cannot select the Legion of the Dead secret, instead they gain access to the following secrets of the pale Warding Bond (Su) The bonded in deaths spiritual bond with their dearly departed is so strong that it wards them from harm while they are in each others presence. While the bonded in death and their dearly departed are within 30 feet of each other they both gain a +2 profane bonus to their AC and their Will saves, and whenever one of them takes damage the other can choose to take half that damage, rounded up (after applying damage reduction, resistances, or the like). This shared damage cannot be reduced or prevented in any way and bypasses any immunities either might possess. Some pale theologians specialize in calling upon the lingering remnants of the soul that cling to the bodies of the dead rather than animating the corpses directly. The pale theologian must select the imbue with unlife ability with their pale imbuement class feature to select this alternate class feature. If they later gain the imbue with unlife ability using the Expanded Imbuement secret, they can choose to gain this alternate class feature and apply it to that ability. Once they make this choice, it cannot be changed. The spectral reanimators imbue with unlife functions as the extract specter spell rather than lesser animate dead. When the duration of this specter expires, it can be extracted from the same corpse again following all the same restrictions as animating an undead create with imbue with unlife. At 5th level, this ability instead functions as greater extract specter, rather than animate dead. This modifies the pale theologians pale imbuement class feature. Special If a pale theologian with a spherecasting archetype selects this alternate class feature, this ability instead functions as the Animate Specter talent. The spectral reanimator cannot select the Legion of the Dead secret, instead they gain access to the following secrets of the pale Awakened Extraction (Su) When the spectral reanimator creates a permanent specter using their imbue with unlife ability they can choose to spend an extra 2 theology points and an additional 25gp worth of onyx per Hit Die of the specter as part of its creation to imbue it with intellect, as extract awakened specter. Special If a pale theologian with a spherecasting archetype selects this secret, it instead functions as the Awaken Specter advanced talent. They must still pay the material components associated with this ability. Champion of the Pale Damned Designator Pale Channeler Pale Invoker Paleweaver Sphere Pale Theologian Unliving Master
benefits: should the bonded in deaths dearly departed be permanently returned to life, they lose the of this alternate class feature and can choose to retrain it at no cost.

name: Secrets of the Pale
description: The pale theologian has learned to replace one of their arms with an undead limb, granting them a touch attack that devastates their foes with pale energies. The pale theologian gains a melee touch attack that deals damage equal to 1d6 damage + their Charisma modifier. This damage causes wounds and lesions to appear across the struck targets flesh, dealing untyped physical damage. This damage bypasses most resistances and immunities, but can be reduced by DR/ and hardness. The pale theologian uses this touch attack as if it were a light melee weapon wielded by the replaced arm for the purposes of attacks, and making attacks using it requires their hand to be free. This touch attack counts as a weapon in the close fighter weapon group, and can be enhanced by feats and abilities that can be used to enhance melee weapons, such as Weapon Focus (arm of undeath). This touch attack can also be enhanced by magic as if it were a natural weapon or an unarmed strike, such as by using magic handwraps or an amulet of mighty fists. This secret can be selected multiple times, once for each of the pale theologians arms. While the pale theologian is infected by a disease, they canspend 1 theology point as a standard action to cause their flesh to spread a foul disease-ridden miasma. This miasma is an aura with a radius of 15 feet that spreads around corners and through small gaps. The pale theologian chooses a single disease they are infected with when they activate this ability and imbues their miasma with that disease. It is treated as an inhaled disease, and any creature within their miasma risks being exposed to it if they breathe within the miasmas area. This miasma persists for 1 minute. At pale theologian level 5, and every 5 levels thereafter, the radius of their miasma increases by 5 feet. If the pale theologian uses this ability while it is already active, the first miasma immediately ends. The pale theologian can always choose to end this ability early as a standard action. This is a supernatural effect. This secret of the pale can be selected multiple times; when selected twice, the pale theologian can have their miasma persist for 10 minutes. When selected a third time, the miasma persists until they choose to end it early as a standard action, or if they activate the ability again. The pale theologian has learned to lace their words with lingering energies that allow them to influence the will of uncontrolled mindless undead. This ability functions just like a Diplomacy check made to improve the attitude of a person, save that the pale theologian rolls 1d20 and adds their pale theologian level and their Charisma modifier to determine the results of this check. Unlike a normal Diplomacy check, the Diplomacy DC of this check is equal to 10 + the mindless undeads Hit Dice to increase their attitude to Friendly, or 20 + the mindless undeads Hit Dice to increase their attitude to Helpful. Should the pale theologian fail, they may not attempt to sway that specific undead for 24 hours. This ability has no effect on mindless undead that are under a creatures control. To use this ability, the pale theologian must spend 1 minute speaking within 30 feet of the undead creature. The undead must be able to perceive the pale theologian, and must not be able to see any other creatures it is Hostile or Unfriendly towards. A mindless undead whose attitude is improved to Friendly will perform actions the pale theologian directs that align within its nature (such as moving to a specific location, defending a locale, or attacking creatures it is naturally hostile towards). The undead generally wont stray too far from the location it was found. A mindless undead whose attitude is improved to Helpful will perform tasks as the pale theologian directs, even if they would go against their nature, much like an undead creature under their command. Attitude shifts caused by this ability last for 1 hour per 5 pale theologian levels. Further attempts against a specific undead creature after the first each day have their DC increased by +5 for each additional attempt. If the pale theologian or their allies attack the undead, its attitude shifts as normal. The pale theologian can also use this ability to influence an undead creature with an Intelligence score of 1 or 2, but they take a -4 penalty on the check. At the GMs discretion, repeated successful uses over many days may allow the pale theologian to permanently affect the starting attitude of an undead creature. The pale theologian uncovers secrets of the divine nature ofthe pale, allowing them to channel its energies. The pale theologian chooses either positive or negative energy when they gain this ability, and can channel the chosen energy, as the cleric class feature, a total number of times per day equal to 3 + their Charisma modifier. The pale theologian does not need a holy or unholy symbol to use this ability. The pale theologian uses their class level in place of their cleric level when determining the saving throw DC of their channeled energy. When the pale theologian channels energy, they can spend 1 theology point to target both living and undead creatures with their channeled energy. This secret can be selected a second time, allowing them to channel the energy type they didnt select. Each time they use this ability, they choose whether they are channeling positive or negative energy. When channeling energy, they can spend 2 theology points to channel both positive and negative energy simultaneously. When doing so, they can choose whether to affect living or undead creatures individually for each energy type. The pale theologians aptitude towards raising the dead has granted them knowledge of rites that can improve their durability. When the pale theologian creates an undead using their imbue with unlife ability, they can spend 1 additional theology point to grant the created undead an additional 2 Hit Points per hit die, a +1 bonus to their CMD, and a +1 increase to their existing natural armor. The granted bonus to their CMD and the increase to their natural armor increases by an additional +1 at levels 6, 10, 14, and 18. The pale theologian chooses an additional ability from the pale imbuement class feature; they gain the ability to use that ability in addition to their initial choice. The pale theologian has learned to infuse their limbs withtheir spiritual essence, allowing them to grasp objects outside their normal reach. The pale theologian can grab, pickup, and interact with unattended objects within their natural reach plus 10 feet. This does not extend their reach with melee weapons, but does allow them to deliver melee touch attacks using this extended reach. This extended reach increases by an additional 5 feet at 6th, 12th, and 18th level. The pale theologian has unearthed ancient and hidden secrets regarding death and undead creatures. They gain a +2 bonus to Heal checks, Knowledge checks regarding funerary rites, religious ceremonies about death, the realms where souls travel to after a living creature dies, and for identifying undead creatures, as well as a +2 bonus to Profession checks involving religious work and the dead. These bonuses increase by an additional +1 at 4th level, and every 2 levels thereafter. Special If you are using the optional rules for the Handle Undead skill, this secret of the pale applies to this skill as well. The pale theologian has learned to animate lesser corpses into a legion under their command using their imbue with unlife ability. Undead the pale theologian can control in this way have a limit to the number of Hit Dice they may possess, and the number of undead they can animate in this way is determined by adding together their class level and their Charisma modifier, and then consulting Table Legion of the Dead. Reanimating these undead requires corpses and costs theology points as normal, and are animated as the imbue with unlife ability. Only normal skeletons and zombies can be animated, not variant or improved undead. These undead do not require expensive material components to create, and do not count against the limit of undead they can control with their imbue with unlife ability or their animate dead spell. These undead have no maximum duration. This secret can be selected multiple times, further empowering the pale theologians legion. They can create and control variant undead using this ability . Any undead they raise into their service with this rite that isnt a normal skeleton or zombie counts an undead of 50% more hit dice (rounded up), when determining its effect Hit Dice for this ability. Thus, the pale theologian can create variant undead with a maximum of 4 Hit Dice using this ability. Additionally, they treat their pale theologian level as 6 higher for the purposes of this ability for each time it is selected after the first. The pale theologian has uncovered commandments that will sway the undead to their will. As a standard action, the pale theologian may spend 2 theology points to attempt to charm a single undead creature, as command undead, for 24 hours. The pale theologian has attained a level of control beyond even the most skilled of necromancers. The pale theologian adds their pale theologian level to the number of Hit Dice of undead they may control using animate dead. This secret can be selected a second time, allowing them to add twice their pale theologian level instead. The pale theologian has learned to channel their deathly powers into a potent contagion. The pale theologian gains the ability to cast contagion as a spell-like ability by spending 1 theology point as a standard action. The pale theologian uses their class level as their caster level with this ability, and their Charisma when determining its saving throw DC. When the pale theologian reaches 9th level, they may cast greater contagion by spending 3 theology points instead. These are supernatural effects. The pale theologians flesh has become hardened and corpselike, granting them a natural armor bonus of +2. This bonus increases by an additional +1 at 4th level, and every 4 levels thereafter. The pale theologian has learned to imbue their body with pale energies, allowing them to survive wounds that would kill most other users of magic. The pale theologian gains an additional +2 hit points per pale theologian level. This secret can be selected twice, its effects stack. The pale theologian has learned to infuse their own organs with pale energies, granting them an incredible resistance to precision strikes. When they are hit by a critical hit or sneak attack, there is a 25% chance that the critical hit or sneak attack is negated and instead rolled normally. This secret can be selected an additional three times. Each additional selection increases the chance to negate a critical hit or sneak atiack by 25% (to a max of 100% when selected four times). This secret does not stack with similar abilities that negate critical hits or sneak attacks, such as the fortification armor property. The pale theologians studies have unveiled some of the secrets of lichdom to them, allowing them to attune their soul to a phylactery. When the pale theologian dies or is destroyed, their soul returns to this phylactery and begins to rebuild their body over three weeks. If their body is destroyed during this process, it begins anew. After this time passes the pale theologian awakens fully healed, albeit with none of the gear that was left on their body when they died. If more than 1 day has passed and the pale theologians phylactery is intact, they cannot be raised from the dead through other means. At any point while their body is being rebuilt the pale theologian can choose to accelerate the process with devastating effects on the resulting body. They may choose to reduce the time it takes their body to rebuild by up to three weeks (reduced in 1 week increments). If they have less than 1 week remaining, they can reduce the duration to 24 hours. This still counts as reducing the duration by 1 week. For each week they reduce the time by, their resulting body gains 1 permanent negative level, even if they are normally immune to negative levels. These negative levels do not kill or destroy the pale theologian, instead, if these negative levels would reduce them to 0 Hit Dice they take 4 points of Charisma drain (even if they are immune to ability drain). The pale theologian immediately knows if their phylactery has been destroyed. If their phylactery is destroyed, they can create a new phylactery, requiring 15 days, and an expenditure of 500 gp per character level. The most common form of phylactery is a sealed metal box containingstripsofparchmentonwhichmagicalphraseshave been transcribed. The box is Tiny and has 40 hit points, hardness 20, and a break DC of 40. Other forms of phylacteries can exist, such as rings, amulets, or similar items. This secret can be selected multiple times. If selected a second time, the time it takes for their body to rebuild is reduced to 2 weeks. If selected a third time, the time is reduced to 1 week. If selected a fourth time, the time is reduced to 24 hours. The pale theologian has learned to further adapt themselves to the magics of death. They add half their class level to their saving throws against death effects, spells of the necromancy school, and any ability that deals negative energy damage. They take no penalty from negative levels gained via energy drain or death effects, though they can still be killed if they accrue more negative levels than they have Hit Dice. After 24 hours, any negative levels they take are removed without the need for an additional saving throw. The pale theologian has developed a technique to bolster a creature with both life and death magics, forestalling the harmful effects of bodily harm upon them. The pale theologian can touch a creature as a standard action and spend 1 theology point to forestall the targets bodily demise. For the next hour, the creature does not suffer the negative effects of any ability damage, ability drain, ability penalties, or negative levels imposed by bleed effects, curses, death effects, diseases, or poisons they are suffering from, and they automatically stabilize if reduced to -1 or fewer hit points. If they are affected by a bleed effect, they are automatically cured of the effect at the end of their turn. This ability does not grant immunity to these effects; they may still gain these conditions, though they do not suffer any penalties unless their ability damage or drain would reduce an ability score to 0 or they would accrue a number of negative levels equal to their Hit Dice, in which case they suffer the normal penalties (death, paralysis, madness, unconsciousness, etc). At 4th level, and every 2 levels thereafter, the duration of this ability increases by 1 hour. The pale theologian learns special rites to manipulate corpses using the magics of the pale, granting them the following abilities The pale theologian can touch a single corpse as a standard action and spend 1 theology point to cause it to immediately decay. The flesh of the corpse immediately bubbles away into a viscous rot, leaving the creature's skeleton behind. For the purposes of raise dead, a decayed corpse is treated as if twice the amount of time has passed when determining if it can be raised. The pale theologian can touch a skeletal corpse as a standard action and spend 1 theology point to restore its flesh, allowing it to be reanimated as a zombie or other type of undead that requires a fleshy corpse. This created flesh does not resemble the creatures flesh in life, is inedible, and cannot be used as a component for spells or abilities that require flesh. This flesh begins to rapidly decay upon its creation, rottng away to nothing after 24 hours unless it is preserved using magic or the corpse is animated as an undead creature. The pale theologian can touch the corpse of a destroyed undead as a standard action and spend 1 theology point and 25gp worth of onyx per Hit Die of the undead to restore it to an intact state, allowing it to be animated once again using animate dead or similar effects. When an undead is reanimated using a restored corpse, it is only reanimated with 1 hit point (it still has its normal maximum hit points). The pale theologian can perform special rites that restore the flesh and spirits of themselves and their allies. Performing these rites takes 1 minute and an expenditure of at least 2 theology points. After these rites are performed, the pale theologian and each of their living or undead allies within 20 feet of them regain 1d6 hit points per pale theologian level. For every 2 additional theology points spent, they regain these hit points an additional time. The pale theologians studies of the pale arts have revealed to them numerous secrets involving undead creatures, including their particular weaknesses or traits. They gain a +2 insight bonus on attack rolls, CMB, and skill checks against undead creatures. These bonuses increase by an additional 1 at levels 6, 10, 14 and 18. If they successfully identify an undead creature using Knowledge (Religion), or using another skill if they have the ability to do so, these bonuses are increased by 50% (rounded up) against that target for 24 hours. As a swift action, the pale theologian can inform an ally who can hear them (or if they can perceive the pale theologian with another method of verbal communication, such as telepathy) with an intelligence score of 3 or greater of information that can assist them against an undead creature of the pale theologians choice within Medium range, granting the ally the bonuses of this ability against that specific undead creature until the beginning of the pale theologians next turn. This secret can be selected a second time, causing this ability to grant its bonus to weapon damage rolls and opposed ability checks against undead, and also grants the pale theologian a dodge bonus to AC against undead. These bonuses are insight bonuses, and are equal to the other bonuses granted by this secretofthepale(andthusareincreasedby50%againstundead they have identified). When the pale theologian grants an ally the bonuses of their lay to rest, they gain these bonuses as well. The pale theologian has infused themselves with spectral energy, causing their muscles to atrophy away while infusing their body with ghostly strength. The pale theologians Strength score becomes . They use their Charisma to determine their carrying capacity and use their Charisma modifier in place of their Strength when making Strength checks and when determining their CMB and CMD. Since the pale theologian has no Strength score, they use their Charisma when making melee attacks. They do not add their Charisma modifier to their damage rolls when doing so. The pale theologians study of death and life magic has granted them unique insights into the working of magic itself, allowing them to infuse a wider array of spells with their specialized casting methodologies. The pale theologian selects a number of cleric or wizard spells equal to their Charisma modifier (minimum 1); they learn these spells and can prepare them without the need of their spellbook, and treat them as their cleric or wizard spell level when treating them as pale theologian spells, rather than their modified level. The pale theologian can only prepare and cast these spells if they have spell slots of the appropriate level to do so, but may choose to learn spells they cannot yet cast if they wish. If the pale theologian later gains a permanent increase to their Charisma modifier, they may select additional spells. If they lose this permanent increase they lose the ability to cast those spells, and if they regain the increase they gain the ability to cast the originally chosen spells again. The pale theologian may also treat these spells as necromancy-school spells for the purposes of their feats and abilities that modify or empower necromancy spells. They cannot combine these abilities with abilities that would affect the spells base school. The spell is still treated as its base school for all other purposes. The pale theologian has gained greater understanding and control over their undead minions, allowing them to sense their presence and share their senses. The pale theologian always knows the location of undead under their control relative to them. As a standard action by spending 1 theology point, the pale theologian can attune their senses to a single one of their undead under their control for 10 minutes.
